factoid: Princess Mary said "No, no. I’ll go out to them."
Princess Mary went out into the porch despite protests from the nurse and Dunyásha.
Dron, Dunyásha, the nurse, and Michael Ivánovich followed Princess Mary into the porch.
Princess Mary thought the crowd probably thinks she is offering them grain to bribe them to remain there.
Princess Mary thought she would leave the crowd to the mercy of the French.
Princess Mary thought she would offer the crowd monthly rations and housing at her Moscow estate.
Princess Mary thought Andrew would do even more if he were in her place.
Princess Mary walked toward the crowd standing on the pasture by the barn in twilight.
Men in the crowd crowded closer together, stirred, and rapidly took off their hats.
Princess Mary lowered her eyes and tripped over her skirt while approaching the crowd.
Princess Mary could not distinguish the faces of the crowd because many eyes old and young were fixed on her.
Princess Mary felt she must speak to the crowd all at once but did not know how.
Princess Mary felt courage because she represented her father and her brother.
Princess Mary began her speech boldly.
Princess Mary said "I am very glad you have come."
Princess Mary felt her heart beating quickly and violently while speaking.
Princess Mary said Drónushka tells her that the war has ruined the crowd.
Princess Mary said the war is their common misfortune.
Princess Mary said she would grudge nothing to help the crowd.
Princess Mary said she was going away because it is dangerous here.
Princess Mary said the enemy is near.
Princess Mary said she is giving the crowd everything.
Princess Mary begged the crowd to take all their grain so they may not suffer want.
Princess Mary said if the crowd has been told she is giving grain to keep them here, that is not true.
Princess Mary asked the crowd to go with all their belongings to her estate near Moscow.
Princess Mary promised she would see to it that the crowd would want for nothing at her estate.
Princess Mary promised the crowd they would be given food and lodging.
Princess Mary stopped speaking.
Sighs were the only sound heard in the crowd.
Princess Mary said she is not doing this on her own account.
Princess Mary said she does this in the name of her dead father, who was a good master to the crowd.
Princess Mary said she does this in the name of her brother and his son.
Princess Mary paused again.
No one broke the silence.
Princess Mary concluded that theirs is a common misfortune and they will share it together.
Princess Mary concluded that all that is hers is theirs.
All eyes were gazing at Princess Mary with one identical expression.
Princess Mary could not fathom whether the expression was curiosity, devotion, gratitude, or apprehension and distrust.
The expression on all faces was identical.
A voice at the back of the crowd said "We are all very thankful for your bounty, but it won’t do for us to take the landlord’s grain."
Princess Mary asked "But why not?"
No one replied.
Princess Mary looked around at the crowd and found that every eye she met dropped immediately.
Princess Mary asked again "But why don’t you want to take it?"
No one answered.
The silence oppressed Princess Mary.
Princess Mary tried to catch someone's eye.
Princess Mary asked "Why don’t you speak?" to a very old man leaning on his stick.
Princess Mary said "If you think something more is wanted, tell me! I will do anything" while catching his eye.
The old man bent his head low and muttered "Why should we agree? We don’t want the grain."
The old man said "Why should we give up everything? We don’t agree."
The old man said "We are sorry for you, but we’re not willing. Go away yourself, alone..."
The crowd responded with various sides: "We’re not willing. Let them ruin us! We won’t take your grain. We don’t agree."
Princess Mary tried again to catch someone's eye but no eye turned to her.
Princess Mary felt strange and awkward because the crowd avoided her look.
